qas.question: What instrument became the predominant keyboard during the classical era?
What became more standardized during the classical era?

answers.text: The basic forces required for an orchestra

qas.question: How many muscians, at most, could make up a chamber ensemble during the classical period?

context: The Classical era, from about <a0_0>1750 to 1820<a0_0/>, established many of the norms of composition, presentation, and style, and was also when <a1_0>the piano<a1_0/> became the predominant keyboard instrument. <a2_0>The basic forces required for an orchestra<a2_0/> became somewhat standardized (although they would grow as the potential of a wider array of instruments was developed in the following centuries). Chamber music grew to include ensembles with as many as 8 to <a3_0>10<a3_0/> performers for serenades. Opera continued to develop, with regional styles in Italy, France, and German-speaking lands. The opera buffa, <a4_0>a form of comic opera<a4_0/>, rose in popularity. The symphony came into its own as a musical form, and the concerto was developed as a vehicle for displays of virtuoso playing skill. Orchestras no longer required a harpsichord (which had been part of the traditional continuo in the Baroque style), and were often led by the lead violinist (now called the concertmaster).
